Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Residential Outcomes for Families Receiving Housing Assistance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study centers on a vital issue facing U.S. society today: how families use limited financial resources to find and maintain suitable housing in desirable neighborhoods when affordable housing is in short supply. This is important since where people live matters for their health, education, and other outcomes. Yet, affordable housing has arguably become less accessible over the past several decades, as housing costs have risen substantially more than incomes. This project tests emerging theories that emphasize that how households search for new housing is both important for residential outcomes and influenced by the conditions of where we have lived and our experiences there, the input and location of our social networks, and our preferences, ideals, and expectations for when and where to move. This study elucidates the links between past residential and social conditions, residential preferences, expectations and ideals (psychosocial factors), the housing search, and current residence. Findings from this work will facilitate decisions that broaden access to homes that meet residents' needs.

This project examines the relationships among residential dynamics for Housing Choice Voucher program participants living with children in a particular county. It employs information from 50-55 qualitative in-depth interviews, longitudinal administrative data from two local public housing authorities, and tract-level data from the U.S. Census Bureau and a regional council. Interviews provide insight into householders' residential histories, social networks, residential psychosocial factors, housing search processes, and residential satisfaction. Quantitative data offer additional background information to assess residential outcomes from before and after a move, according to commonly used measures of household and neighborhood socioeconomic context. Using the combination of qualitative and quantitative data facilitates the comparison of outcomes according to standard socioeconomic measures and participants' reported residential satisfaction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the conditions of residential moves for households using Housing Choice Vouchers in King County, Washington, the center of a tight and relatively newly developed western U.S. metropolis. Specifically, it sought to understand why households move, where and for how long they searched for housing, what they were looking for in a home and community, and whether they preferred their current or most recent homes and neighborhoods.

The primary data for this project came from January 2019-February 2020 interviews with 54 parents or grandparents living with at least one child or adolescent and using—for at least two years—a voucher within Seattle Housing Authority’s (SHA) or King County Housing Authority’s (KCHA) service area (covering nearly all of King County). Data from HUD Form 50058, the U.S. Census Bureau, and Opportunity Insights added to the picture drawn from the interviews. 

  To gain a sense of how the research outcomes may differ based on racialization and residential backgrounds (including country of origin), colleagues and I spoke with people across five racialized groups (Black, White, Latinx, Asian, and Multiracial or No Race) and in four languages (English, Somali, Spanish, and Vietnamese); we also asked questions about the kinds of places participants had lived in the past and what their experiences were like there. By speaking to a such a broad range of households, we expand the voices included in related research. Still, because of the non-random nature of the data collection, readers should exercise caution when generalizing especially the context-specific results.

  Overall, this research bolsters our knowledge about on-the-ground processes of racialized inequality, which housing service providers can leverage to improve their services and academic researchers can build on to elucidate these forces further. This project is among the first to test novel theories about residential stratification that emphasize the neighborhood selection and housing search processes, as well as the residential histories and social networks that shaped them. Findings suggest that residential backgrounds vary by race, ethnicity, and country of origin in ways that align with broader patterns of residential stratification and demonstrate consistencies across residential histories.

  The racialized residential histories I observed shaped group differences in housing searches and outcomes. Importantly, voucher-related discrimination was a common experience and hurdle for housing searchers across the board and racism introduced additional challenges for some people of color, especially U.S.-born Black individuals. Many people strategized to avoid or overcome possible further discrimination, which meant additional work for those facing possible racism.

  The roles of social networks varied substantially and whether a mover found a place through the advice or help of another individual was racialized. While most people overall found their homes without assistance, a small number of especially Black and Vietnamese householders came across their specific home or neighborhood through a personal or organizational contact (e.g., a case worker or a staff person at a doctor’s office), the latter of which typically spurred a move out of the community of origin. Whether personal connections contributed to a move within or outside of the community of origin depended on the group, with such U.S.-born Black participants typically moving to more distant areas—perhaps reflecting contextual factors like the splintering of this group from its formerly more centralized community—and foreign-born Black and Vietnamese respondents receiving recommendations that led to moves within the area they had already been living in.

  It is revealing that other forms of social support during moves were also racialized. For example, U.S.-born Black movers reported facing disproportionate hurdles with housing searches, in part since they most often experienced long housing searches with periods of homelessness. They also commonly reported staying with a family member, friend, or acquaintance between homes. This may reflect their higher likelihood of needing such support, which aligns with their general residential disadvantage. At the same time, it is noteworthy that this group had substantial social resources to draw on when necessary. 

  Finally, while much research on residential quality often employs a similar set of widely-used measures (e.g., percent in income poverty), I examine outcomes based on both standard measures and residential satisfaction, in part to test for any possible inconsistencies. Assessments of neighborhoods constituted one form of incongruence between commonly used measures of residential attainment and how interview participants rated their living conditions. Especially foreign-born Black and Vietnamese participants preferred their current neighborhoods, despite them being areas with higher levels of income poverty. Many U.S.-born Black participants who had grown up locally reported similarly positive sentiments about their tight-knit former communities in segregated, predominantly Black, and socioeconomically underserved Seattle areas. In line with many of the other findings, some respondents of color, especially U.S.-born Black individuals, most commonly reported experiences of racism living in predominantly White or Asian areas, casting a negative light over their assessments of these sometimes lower poverty neighborhoods.
